wikipedia_page.main: Walter Louis Bradfield (1866–1919), was an English actor and singer who starred in Edwardian musical comedy and other theatrical works.

response: *Dick Cunningham (tenor) – W. Louis Bradfield (later replaced by Farren Soutar)
*Guy Stanley (Lord Coodle's Nephew) – W. Louis Bradfield

A Gaiety Girl is an English musical comedy in two acts by a team of musical comedy neophytes: Owen Hall (book, on an outline by James T. Tanner), Harry Greenbank (lyrics) and Sidney Jones (music).  It opened at Prince of Wales Theatre in London, produced by George Edwardes, on 14 October 1893 (later transferring to Daly's Theatre) and ran for 413 performances.  The show starred C. Hayden Coffin, Louie Pounds, Decima Moore, Eric Lewis, W. Louis Bradfield, and later Rutland Barrington, Scott Russell, Huntley Wright, Marie Studholme and George Grossmith, Jr.  Topsy Sinden and later Letty Lind danced in the piece.  Choreography was by Willie Warde. Percy Anderson designed the Japanese costumes for the musical, while the non-Japanese costumes were supplied by leading fashion houses."Gaiety Girls in The Geisha". Victoria and Albert Museum, accessed 4 August 2011  Blanche Massey was one of the Gaiety Girls in the piece.  It also had a successful three-month Broadway run in 1894, followed by an American tour and a world tour.
:Bobbie Rivers - W. Louis Bradfield (later replaced by Farren Soutar)

In Town was first produced by George Edwardes at the Prince of Wales Theatre, opening on 15 October 1892, and transferred to the Gaiety Theatre on 26 December 1892, running for a successful 292 performances.Hollingshead, John.  Good Old Gaiety: An Historiette & Remembrance (1903)  London:Gaity Theatre Co., p. 74  It starred Arthur Roberts, together with Edmund Payne, Eric Lewis, and singing star Florence St John."Prince of Wales's Theatre", The Times, 17 October 1892, p. 13  Topsy Sinden danced in the piece.The Era,  4 June 1898, p. 10 The musical was produced on Broadway, for a run of 40 performances, opening on 6 September 1897 at the Knickerbocker Theatre, starring W. Louis Bradfield as Arthur Coddington and Marie Studholme as Kitty.Bordman, Gerald. "American musical theatre: a chronicle", p. 175, Oxford University Press US, 2001 Kenrick, John. Stage Musical Chronology: The 1890s: Part II - 1895 to 1899 , Musicals101.com, 2003, accessed January 28, 2012Briscoe, Johnson.  The actors' birthday book, p. 103 (1908) Moffat, Yard and Company
* W. Louis Bradfield (1866–1919), English actor and singer
* Lagorille, The Incroyable – W. Louis Bradfield

Another American trip took place in 1897. After a two-week try-out at the Garrick, Edwardes sent a company to New York to play In Town; Nesville's colleagues in the company included W. Louis Bradfield and Marie Studholme. Nesville's role, Juliette Breville, was an addition to the original version, written specifically for her."The London Theatres", The Era, 14 August 1897, p. 9 She remained in New York to repeat her role of Sally Lebrune, in The Triumph of the Philistines."American Amusements", The Era, 23 October 1897, p. 11 The Geisha was still running in London when she returned, and she rejoined the cast."Theatrical Gossip", The Era, 13 November 1879, p. 12 She spent much of 1898 in a succession of engagements at the Alhambra music hall in Leicester Square, singing selections from the shows in which she had appeared. In May 1899 she was engaged to return to Paris, singing in a revival of Le voyage de Corbillon at the Folies-Dramatiques,"Theatrical Gossip", The Era, 20 May 1899, p. 12, and creating the role of Nina in a new "vaudeville-opérette", Madame Pistache."The Drama in Paris", The Era, 17 June 1899, p. 13 Les Annales du théâtre et de la musique thought her the best thing about the production.Noël and Stoullig, 1900, p. 309 Back in London in September she created her last West End role, a French maid, in a new farce, The Elixir of Youth: "no more roguish, mischievous little cocquette has been seen for a long time on the stage than Miss Juliette Nesville's Suzette", commented The Era."The Elixir of Youth", The Era, 16 September 1899, p. 13
